div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE WAR OF THE FUTURE.
div.p: Yesterday's telegrams container! a significant announcement of the opinion of the American Press as to the inevitableness of the war between Japan and the United States. The trouble has only just commenced, hut as the 1 Spectator" remarks in an article on the subject it may rapidly become serious. The yellow peoples are very proud and very sensitive.

They do not acknowledge—as, for example the negroes have hitherto done—that there are any inherent inequality between themselves and the white men ; and, not acknowledging it, the weight of argument is entirely upon their side. They do not even understand why their "intrusion" is disliked, and they see their way to reprisals which might in certain contingencies—-as, for instance, a great European war—develop into active hostilities. The subject should therefore be dealt with before the Governments have caught fire, and while the classes which are not affected inboth sets of countries are prepared to listen to reasonable argument.

That argument should, we think, be based upon the assumption, that the races will, for the present at all events, do well to keep apart. Their instinctive hostility—or shall we say jealousy?- may, and probably will gradually die away; but it has lasted for ages, and has become in the course of those ages one of the fixed conditions of thought end feeling among the masses, making a just equality of treatment for the moment nearly impossible. The Far Eastern States, for example, cannot confine their »migration to families only, and families of the I test character, while the white States cannot coerce their uneducated populations into accepting their yellow competitors as friends and helpers. The movement, if it became general, must inevitably develop small industrial civil wars; and diplomatists may on that ground alone use all their energies to prevent by agree-ment what must otherwise prove a disturbing contact, in the absence of which peace between the races might reign for ages.

But, the diplomatists will ask with reason, on what lines are we to suggest agreements I They will be difficult to arrange, hut they are not altogether impossible As we understand the matter, none of the Far Eastern Govern-ments are particularly anxious that their subjects should emigrate. On the Other hand, Europeans and Americans of the working class do not seek the Far Eastern States as places for settlement. It must therefore be possible for the Governments on both sides to discourage emigration; and, for instance, the Government of India now does whenever the demand comes from pièces which it considers unsuitable under the prevailing conditions, or unwholesome by reason of climate. That Government has once or twice used its reserved power to control emigration in a very decided way, once nearly milling the colony of Réunion, for example, which depended upon« supply of Indian labour, when it suspected or knew that the emigrants, under a delusion about the danger from cholora, were being-harshly treated These government once made, the question would be under the official control of the responsible Governments, who might, by introducing a passport system, prevent over-numerous immigration without preventing, or even restricting, the ordinary movements of commerce or shipping. They could pass all traders' agents or bagmen, while forbidding coolies to lie taken on hoard. Diplomatists may easily make better suggestions than this, but this is the object they should seek, and seek now, before overwhelming demand or habit of .'migration renders "precautions hopeless, or so burdensome to great "interests" that the Foreign Offices would try to longer retain a free hand. They may rely on it that it will be many years, perhaps many decades, before the jealousy of the white workmen will subside; while it is most, unreasonable to expect that the For Eastern populations, which are so steadily claiming their place in the arrangements of the world, will for ever bear to see their children insulted and injured because of an abstract theory that their presence is injurious to alien civilizations, For the moment the Foreign (Justices may imagine that the East can make no effective reprisals, and therefore they may neglect the subject ; but that is an illusion resembling that of the Russian statesmen who fancied, before the war, that Japan was a little Bower which, even if it felt affronted, could he safely defied or coerced. These States are not minor Bowers, but are as sensitive as if they were; and if affronted, they may find means of asserting themselves which will produce a sense, if not of dismay, at least of perplexity in very great Governments indeed.

div.head: Egyptian Directory
div.p: The "Annnaire Egyptian" for 1907 has been printed, and the volumes are now in the hands of the bookbinders. They will be distributed and on sale in a few days' time.

div.head: Cattle Plague
div.p: During the week ending January 28 six cases of bovine typhus were reported for the whole of Egypt. Three took plaoe in the Fashn district and three near Beni Maiar.

div.head: Egyptian Shipbuilding
div.p: During last year six steamships, of 2,666 tons gross, and two sailing vessels, of 1,200 tons gross, were launched in the United Kingdom for Egypt. In 1905 only one vessel was launched, and in 1904 six.

div.head: Hotel Semiramis.
div.p: As already announced, the inauguration of the Semiramis Hotel, Cairo, will take place on Thursday, 7th inst. There will be a reception daring the afternoon, and a dinner and a grand ball in the evening. Numerous invitations have been sent out.

div.head: Savoy Fancy Dress Ball.
div.p: The management of the Savoy Hotel have decided to issue invitations for a fancy-dress ball on Tuesday, 19th inst. These annual balls are always among the events of the season, and this one will doubtless be as successful as any of those of past years.

div.head: Captain Spelterini.
div.p: Those in search of a novel entertainment should not miss the opportunity offered by a lantern lecture with slides from instantaneous photographs taken from the balloon by Captain Spelterini, the famous aeronaut, which is to be given at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, tomorrow, at 9.80 p.m. The views to be shown are those taken above the Alps and id Egypt, and the lecture is to be delivered in English by Mr. J. W. Congdon. We can heartily recommend the lecture as one of extreme and unusual interest.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: THe Suez Canal reciepts for January were Fr. 9,207,939.21 as against Fr. 9,578,609.79 for January 1906. The passenger returns for the month were 21,035 viz., 7,000 civilians, 7,972 military, and the 6,065 pilgrims. The nationality of the military passengers was as follows: - 4,950 British, 1,007 Germans, 850 French, 730 Turkish, 237 Dutch, 166 Portugese, and 32 Italian. The total shipping for the month was 340,153 northward and 187 southward boud; 207 being British, 45 German, and 22 French.

div.head: New Khedivial Hotel.
div.p: We are glad to note that the new management of the New Khedivial Hotel, Cairn, is making itself felt, and that the hotel is gaining in public favour. Mr. J. Vooles, the present manager, is running the house is strict accordance with the principles of a family hotel and meeting with deserved success. Among the visitors staying there was of note the names of Admiral and Mrs. Dickins Mrs. Wyly, Mrs. Woostor, Mrs. Subring, Mrs Merril, Mr. Beresford, Mr. Tod, Mrs. Moffat, Mrs. FillioD, Miss Blanc, Dr. and Mrs. Asfar Mr., Mrs., and Miss Trad, Mr. and Mrs Ziensen, Mr. and Mrs. Lineskal, Mr. and Mrs Bpagnolo, Mr. and Mrs. d'Broille, Mrs. E Bilberman, Mr. and Mrs Nicole, Mr. and Mrs. Miller

div.head: Recital At Shepherds
div.p: Miss Julie written is rapidly establishing he fame in Cairo for her marvelous cleverness a palmist, and .on Friday she hopes to add to her repertoire by appearing before the public as a "racontense." Under the name of Hope Hathaway she has already charmed her audiences in London with her clever sketches and humorous recitals ; and her appearance in this capacity will be doubly welcome in Cairo, where such entertainments are almost unknown. The first of her ' One-hour recitals will take place at Shepheard's Hotel at 9 o'clock on Friday evening ; the tickets being fixed is the moderate prices of 20 and 10 piastros Mil Critten hopes to give a series of these recitals at the other hotels in Cairo, and doubtless she will meet with a hearty reception.

div.head: Motorcar Plunges Into the Sea
div.p: A singular mishap occurred yesterday evening, about six o'clock, in Alexandria habour the scene of the accident being quay No. 1 The motor 'bos of the New Victoria Hotel was standing there waiting for passengers from JJ Moss 8.3. Menepthat, when, owing to a roar (engines were reversed, and before the oar could be stopped it plunged into to no's, four fathoms deep. A tremendous ensued as soon as the car touched the sea the cold water presumably affecting the vap riser and the cylinders, causing them to bur with a loud reverberation, much to the alar of a large crowd of bystanders. The chanffe managed to jump off in time. It is possible that the oar may be recovered this afternoon Divers report that structural damage is but slight.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA'S PORT-
div.p: HARBOUR IMPROVEMENTS.-
PROGRESS OF A GREAT WORK.

Considerable progress has been made of late in the great works intended to improve the accommodation of the port of Alexandria. The four most important undertakings are : (1) the insurance of the outer harbor at the cost of L.E. 120,000 by prolonging the great break water and by throwing out a breakwater From the new cattle port quay; f2) thpcoo- dtrnotion of three new timber quays for six ships ; (3) the construction of a new coal quay for eight ships;, (4) the construction of the Arsenal quay with berths for four ships ; (5) the creation of a new pass capable of allowing tho largest commercial steamer to pass safley in and out of the port in all weathers, and, in conjunction with the existing pass, to provide an alternative exit and egress, in ease of a block in one of them. We will deal with the present state of each of these works in the order given above.
THE BREAKWATER

The two branches of the breakwater will be each 450 metres in length. The extension from the land side, which juts out from the quarantine pail port, has only just begun to be made, and will not be finished before May 1st, 1908. The work on the prolongation of the great breakwater began last August, and already one hundred metres op to the level of the sea have been built. Three hundred metres have been constructed to a distance of three mrtres below sea level. The whole extent of this branch will be complete next November.
TIMBER QUAYS

The new quays for the timber ships are situated between the Kamarieh harbonr and the graving dock The embankments are complete op to the beginning of the molos, and a hundred metros of the first mole are finished.

A million cubic metres of earthworks have been executed, and a thousand block of concrete, twelve cubic metres each. are ready to be placed in position. All the three quays will be finished and ready to receive ships by the 1st March, 1908.
COAL QUAYS

Two berths of the new coal quays were finished last March. A third berth was completed in December last, and a fourth last month The fifth berth will be ready by-next August. The three other berth«, of the total of eight, will be ready by the 1st January, 1909. The construction of the new timber and coal quays is most necessary to prevent the in further congestion of the port. In 1895, 615.000 tons of coal wore imported. In 1905 this figure rose to 1,132 635 tons, and last year to 1,109,754 tons. Thu value of the wood imported in 1895 was L.E . 496,030. It, 190.5 the wood imports amounted to L.B. 1,329,219 in value.
ARSENAL QUAY

Two berths, together with the sheds, will be handed over by the engineer on the 1st January next. Two others will be completed by the first June 1908. The site of the old jetty attached to this quay, which was made in 1810. has already been partly dredged, and 200.000 square 'Cubic metres of embankment have been constructed there. The old walls will be utilized for the works.
THE NEW PASS

Vessels will be able to use the now pass from next July. The advantage of the new pass, in view of the continual increase in the size of commercial steamers, is obvious. Although, in perfectly smooth water, tho largest commercial steamer. When in light draught not exceeding 28 feet, might enter the port with safety, they could not do so if laden with cargo, or during bad weather ,and, in any case, might, after entering, be indefinitely detained in the port until they could leave with safety. All these difficult tasks will he things of the past by next July. The work has necessitated considerable labour. Two hopper barges, a dredged, and a tug I arrived last year for the enterprise. dredged total cost was about L.E. 50,060 and they wore supplied by Symouds of Reufrew. The British Admiralty lent the Egyptian Government two powerful rook dredgers They have been at work for some time, and have nearly finished the new pass. The Admiralty dredgers have contributed greatly to the economy of the undertaking, and have proved them elves admirably adapted for the work, making it impossible to dispense with the delay and expense of blasting operations.

div.head: MINISTRY OF JUSTICE.
div.p: A MUCH-DISCUSSED APPOINTMENT.

The question of the appointment of a new resident of the Native Court of Appeal be dubbed a considerable amount of discussion in le native and European Press, and complaint live been read that the probable passing over to Afifi Bey in favor of Yehia Bey Ibrahim is mtrary to the regulations of the Ministry. ; is also stated that Yehia Bay is junior not aly to Fig Bey, but to Magda Bay. 'and .tuned Bey Zulfioar.

But as a matter of fact Magda Bey and Yehia ay Ibrahim entered the Court of Appeal on 10 game day (June 27, 1892), while Zifikat Bey was only appointed on February 29, 1896. in any case the appeal of a Cairo contemporary ) the Deoreo of November, 1893, appears to s beside the mark. Art. 11 of this Deoree that "L'avanoement d'une olasse k nne at re, d'une mime fonotion k one autre, auront eu en tenant compto du mfritt et di rancitn itf des oandidats." This article is of general application placed in Section I of the Decree des Magistrate" and does not refer to an; judicial appointment In any case it is explicitly »ted that "merit" most be reckoned with juiority in the choice of a magistrate, and in raotice penior judges have been passed ovei or the posts of vice-president or president of a 'oort on the ground that they did not posses so requisite authority and the necessary administrative ospioity. In this case we understand that the Minister of Justice and the dioial Advisor have been advised by competent authorities as to the merits of the conditions for the presidency of the Native Court of Appeal. Under the circumstances we do not assume what grounds the cry of "injustice" has been raised by one of our contemporaries wit! Reference to the appointment in question.

div.head: EXPEDITION IN THE FAYOUM.
div.p: Professor Osborn, of the American Museum of Natural History, has left Mena House Hotel for the northern Fayopm desert, accompanied by Mr. H. F. Farrar, of the Government Qaologioal Survey, and Messrs. Granger and Olsen, of his own staff. The object of the party is to further explore for the extinct mammalia discovered by the Geological Bur vey in 1902, and recently described by Mr. C. U. Andrews, of the British Museum. The most widely known of the fossils ate the small an ancestors of the elephants and the large horned quadrupeds named Arsinrctheria fter the ancient Egyptian Queen Arsinde. The British authorities, and especially Captain H. G. Lyons, director of the Geological Survey, have greatly facilitated the expedition. The members of Professor Osborn's staff have had prolonged training in their explorations in the deserts of the Rocky Mountain region, and it is hoped that the knowledge of the life of Egypt in Eocene and times may be still more widely extended.

div.head: THE UNION BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: A new bank is shortly to be established in Egypt entitled the Union Bank of Egypt. Fine premises are to be built for the Cairo head- office.

div.head: PLAGUE AT JEDDAH.
div.p: A telegram from Jeddah states that two fresh cases of plague have occurred there.

div.head: A REMARKABLE ESCAPE.
div.p: On Sunday afternoon, the children of Mr. Alexander Alderson, of Ramleh, while driving with their governess and nurse, were precipitated into the canal-drain ty the side of the road leading from the Mahraoudieh Canal to Sidi Gaber. It is supposed that the wheel of the sakieh frightened one of the horses, which fell, dragging the other horse and the carriage down the steep side of the drain (a drop of about four metres). The occupants of the carriage all rolled into the dirty, muddy water. Fortunately, the nurse retained her hold of the baby, and those were the wily ones not com-pletely immersed. 0 1 being polled oat by tho coachman (who behaved splendidly throughout) has oh'ldrou failed, for the moment, to re-ogoise each other, so hjsmeared were they with mud. It is a matter fur congratulation that so little harm was done by what might have been a very serious acidenta, for, had the arriage pinned its occupants beneath it, it is difficult to see how all could have been saved. As it was, beyond a slight bruise sustained by the ooaohman and a good deal of damage to tho carriage, no ono was any the worse for the upset. The horse, escaped injury except for a few cats. At the' moment of the accident Dr. Beytzand Mr. Nowan Antone were driving past and kindly took the dripping, mud-stained party home in their carriages.

We hear that the Municipality has had the orientation of covering this drain for some time. This is now the second accident that has occurred at this spot, and it is some satisfaction Io know that the work is to be began at once.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: Tho Ellerman liner Fabian sailed from Malta last evening, and is doe here on Friday morning with a general cargo.
The Ellerman liner Egyptian arrived at Liverpool last Sunday.
The Moss liner Menepthah arrived yesterday afternoon from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head:
A. S. C.
QUESTION OF NEW SITE.
div.p: Sooner or later the present site of the Alexandria Sporting Club will have to be changed, for owing to the great rise in the value of building land in the immediate neighborhood of the city the site will become too valuable to remain in its present condition. The discussion of the pros and coos of this question has again come forward and a great deal of support is being given in favor of Soof. There is a considerable extent of unoccupied laud there, and as it is near San Stefano and the Palace of the Khedivial Mother, it cannot be considered too far from Ramleh for the purpose.

Prince Omar Pasha Toolson, who is the president of the Alexandria Sporting Club, is in favor of the Sioux scheme, and it is anp ported by many local sportsmen, who consider that the project of transferring the A. 8. C. to Naught is to be deprecated claiming the space there is too cramped for a good racecourse. Moreover, Nouxha is too out-of- the- way for both the inhabitants of Ramleh as well as the Alexandrians and aff ords none of the advantages of Soof for the reaction of a splendid hippodrome. The latter is only a quarter of an hour from Alexandria by motorcar and is convenient of access from tho R imleh line. The wide stretch of open country there is fat more suitable tor a racecourse than the umbrageous park-like gardens of Nouxha. Those beautiful gardens and delightful walks would have to be hopelessly maned to make win for a race course and all the other ape- appurtenances of a Sporting Club.

Another alternative scheme is the Badura Lakeside. The lake would have to be drained, which would not be a very difficult task, and the site is convenient. But it may well be argued that in years to come, owing to the enormous expansion of A exedra towards the east, this site will be in time found to fall a prey to the builder just as is the existing site. No snob objection can be urged against the Ohio of Sioux. In such a case as the selection of a new site for the Alexandria Sporting Club it is most necessary to look as far forward as possible, and from this point of view the Sioux site is unexceptionable.

Orb exhalent confrere the "Pare d' Alex- Andrei" recently published an interesting article on this question, and strong'; supported the schema of Prince Omar Pa h t Toussaint. His Highness's idea is also, in our opinion, a very happy one, and deserves local support. Sooner or later the new site of the Alexandria Sporting Club will have to be chosen, and tho sooner a definite decision is arrived at the better for the lab and its members. Prince Omar is to be congratulated on raising the question, and we hope that his idea will receive the support that it merits.

BRITISH PROTESTANT CEMETERY (OLD CEMETERY).

The R. M. S. Isis arrived hare this afternoon from England after having undergone repairs and will take her usual ran with the Brindisi mail next week. The S.S. Peninsular, which has been carrying the mails doing the absence of the Isis, will, after transferring the mail on Wednesday, continue her journey to Bombay, where she will resume her usual run.
There was a 'Bachelors' Ball" at the Eastern Exchange last Friday. This boing the first English dance this season, there was a good attendance, and a very enjoyable evening was passed.

On Saturday the Port Said Club gave one of their delightful balls in the club rooms. About 150 guests were present, among whom we noticed H.E. the Governor, Judge Bond, the Italian and Greek Consuls, and Mr. Demount Dancing was kept up till after 4.80 a.m.

div.head: VICTORIA COLLEGE.
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE ' Egyptian GAZETTE " Sir,—With reference to 'Casual Observer's" letter dated January 29 on this subject, I beg to say that I have no desire to add an ought to any of the figures contained in my letter of the 28th. Since writing my last letter I have enquired of Mr. Preston as to the actual weights of the girders and joists used in the construction of the College and out- buildings and am informed that the exact quantity is 454 tons, and not 10,000, IS estimated by "Casual Observer," so that my estimate was not far off tho correct amount.

I am pleased to think that I am sufficiently advanced in my profession to be able to distinguish between hundreds and thousands of tons, which Bourns to be beyond the power of a mere ''Casual Observer."—Yore truly, "ENGINEER."

div.head: To MR. "CASUAL OBSERVER."
div.p: Sir,—When you pay your visit to the office of the hen. see. of the Victoria College according to invitation, would you mind ei quiring if there is anything British about this building, except the Please let me know the results of your investigations in the usual way, and oblige,—Yours faithfully,

div.head: EAST AND WEST.
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
Sir,— At the banquet that was held in honor of Mr. Robert on,. M.P., Mr. Dicey is reported to have said the following, which I translate from "Al Minibar" : —

'The longer I stay in your bountiful country which I consider a second home to me ( I 1 I) I become convinced that between East and West there is a great abyss that cannot be roosted from either side."
In other words, he reiterates the two notorious lines of Kipling's :
East is East, and West is West,
The twain she'll I ever meet.

In answer I beg to refer Mr. Dioecy to the following excerpt from "A People In School," by More Fielding Hall, if I remember correctly. She says : "There is no such thing as the Oriental mind, it. is only an expense for all dullness."? In other words, E.st and West are a twain that may and will meet, and they have already met in favor of the former—the war o' Russia and Japan are not far away from us.
— Yours truly,

div.head: THE BRITISH CLUB.
div.p: The second annual general meeting of members of the British Club, Alexandria, was held on Saturday night', and was well attended. The accounts for 1906 were passed, and the hon. treasurer's statement of the financial position of the lung was considered satisfactory. The rules, with slight modifications, were confirmed, and the following were elected to term together with 'he Finance Committee, which remains in force for two more years, the General Committee for 1907: Messrs. A. R Brown, T F Donovan, J G Hewett, J Liligers L'gage, Lou b, A. H M Harris. Randolph, Rolf Waddington, and the Rev. A. H. Longley. M . W F Sa-jeaiit was elected chairman, and Mr. P. W. Carver reelected hon. treasurer. The appointment of hon secretary was left to the General Comitten, who met later on and elected Mr. W. J Webb.

div.head: BRITISH RECREATION CLUB
div.p: A highly successful smoking concert was held in the British Recreation Club, Cairo, on Saturday 2nd inst. A large and varied programme was submitted and carried through with every sign of appreciation on the part of a full attendance. Panototre selections by Private James and Mr. C, Summers, cello solos by Band Sargeant Geogehegan, and violin solos by Bandsman Hobbs, were rendered with taste and feelingand especially so this applies to the celo solos of Sergeant Geoghegan, who showed the touch of a master in all his effortsand the repeated calls for encores to these artists proved their acceptance to the audience. Private Parrington, in his songs, "The Toilers: and :big Ben," Mr. Allen, in "walking out with Angelina: and "My Havannah Queen," Mr. S Ades in "I love you in velvet" and "The man behind", and Mr Carins in "what did I do?" and "Stop yer tickling' Jock," were enjoyable items, which were received with approbation and recalled in every instance. Trooper Fairclough showed his versatility in a skirt dance, the execution of which and his dress and general "get-up" revealed a close study of the music hall skirt dancer. Sapper Goodwin, in his songs, I'll be up your way next week" and "Ding Dong" literally "brought down the house" the former especially being received with uproarious mirth; his song following these, "The song that will live forever," proved him and equally capable artist even in a more serious vein. Piper McConnaschie and Day aroused the enthusiasm of the audience to a high pitch by a stately and dignified rendering of the sword to Piper McConnaschie's dancing, and to repeated calls they gave a combined selection of the bagpipes including a march ("Barren Rocks O'Aden") strathspey ("Miss Drummond of Perth") and reel ("My wooers be merry"). AN enjoyable evening culminated with "God save the King." A word of praise is due to Mr. C. Summers, the moving spirit of the entertainments committee, who worked indefatigably in organizing the smoker, and not only found time to well marshal his musical forces, but to contribute personally to the programme.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Duke of Norfolk, who is arriving in . Egypt immediately with the Duchess of Norfolk, has never been greatly given to foreign travel. Rome, of course, sees him on occasions, but the Bari Marshal of England is often to be found in the home country. Overseas, to be sure, he has of late years been once ; but that was when the Postmaster General resigned his office, and the captain of Sussex Yeomanry went to do yeoman's service in South Africa with his people.

Lord Alan Ian Percy, second heir to the Dukedom of Northumberland after his brother Bari Percy, who is unmarried, has joined the Egyptian Army with the rank of Bombastic and has been posted to the Khartoum di-introit. He was a Lieutenant in the Grenadier Guards and served in South Africa in 1901.

Lady Caroline Gordon Lennox has returned to Loudon from Goodwood House, Chi Chester, and haves London in a few days for Egypt. Lady Caroline is a sister of the Duke of Rahmel and aunt of Lady Muriel Beckwith, who has been at Cairo for some time, her husband boing stationed with the Coldstream C cards.
The Earl and Countess of Lovelace are coming to 'Egypt about the middle of the month.

Captain Forbes and Lady Helen Forbes are passengers by the Orient-Pacific liner Ophir for Egypt. Earl Egerton of Tafton and the Dottithoes of Buckingham and C band is and Lady Clarke are also passengering by the same vessel

The passengers who left London lab week for Gibraltar, Marseilles, Port SAID, Aden, and Bombay in London : Prince of Coop- Behar, Major-General Been Powdl, Hon. R, F. Wilbraham-Bootleg, Sit E. C. and Lady Cox, Sir Philip Grey Egerton, Lady E. Hewett, Lady Antonia Maude, the Earl and Countess of Merth, the Hood. Mrs. C. Monk, Lady North, Comte de la Pasture, and Sir E. W. Robinson.
Sir William Gerstein will visit Asouzo on inspection during the work.
Ahmed Razip Bey, the well-known Young Turk leader, has arrived at Cairo, and will stay for several weeks in the Capital.

div.head: ENTERTAINMENT
div.p: There will be a CONCERT and DRAMATIC ENTERTAINMENT by Distinguished Amateurs at the Theatre, Mullah Pasha Barracks, in aid of the nursing branch of the Sailors and Soldiers' Families' Association, on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday evenings, the 21st, 22nd. and 28rd of February, at nine o'clock.
PRICES OF ADMISSION.

On Thursday and Saturday nights 6 P.T. and 2 P.T. (payable at the door). On Friday (Staff night) admission by ticket only. Reserved Beats numbered. Single Tickets 20 P.T. Family Tickets (to admit three) for P.T. Tickets for Friday, 22nd February, can be obtained from the following ladies: Mrs. Chapman, Ramleh; Mrs. Borton, Mohaheov Bey ; Mrs. Maspheraon Grant, Menatapha, and also from the Officers' Mess, Mastapba.

The Times' learns from Washington that there is reason to believe that President Roosevelt has arranged, through diplomatic channels, an understanding with Japan, and proposes to lay this provisional agreement before the Californian school officials and appeal direct to their common-sense and patriotism to affect a settlement.
The Mayor and members of the Board of Education have started for Washington to discuss the Japanese question with President Roosevelt.
(Reuter}
The war talk in the American press has beet received with surprise and regret. It is declared here that America is the last country with which Japan would like to go to war. (R)

div.head:
KING IN PARIS
INTERVIEW- WITH GERMAN AMBASSADOR.

div.p: The informal character of the visit of the King and Queen was evidenced on Saturday evening by their sudden visit to the Nuova Cirque, of which the manager only receive, the briefest notice. Their Majesties were not cognized.
(Reuter)
Prince de Radolin had a hall-hour's conversation with the King at the British Embassy today.'Their Majesties lunched at Versailles an visited the Museum and Chateau. (Reuter)
M. Failures will give a lunch to Kin Edward on Wednesday. (Havas)
The Sultan has applied to the Powers for a joint loan of £400,000, which, he pleads, is intended to meet the expenses oi the expeditions against El Raisuli and the Pretender.
(Reuter)
The Parliamentary Committee, appointed to preapre the annexation of the Congo, threatens to break up unless the King furnishes documents which up to the present have been withheld.
(Reuter)

M. Briand is preparing a circular to be issued to the prefects specifying teh conditions under which leases are grantable to parish priests for the legal use of churches. In the meantime, the bishops and clergy are applying to the local authorities.
(Reuter)
The philanthropist Osiris is dead. He has left a legacy of 25 million francs to the Pasteur Institute.
(havas)

div.head: FOOTBALL
div.p: CAIRO SHIELD (SECOND ROUND)
2nd Batt. Royal: Inniskilling Fusiliers
versus
3rd. Batt. Coldstream Guards.
The above teams met on Friday last at Ghezriher, to see who should enter the final of the above shield.

About 3,000 spectators were present when the Inskillings, having won the toss, elected to kick with the wind in their favor. THe Guards started the ball a-rolling. The Irishmen at once took play in hand. The ball finding touch, the Household Brigade were seeming to advantage, but Lyons relieved, relieved was in a trio transferred towards the Guards' citadel, where Higginson), receiving a nice pass from Walsh, had no trouble in opening the score for the Innskillings, amidst tonified excitement. On resuming, the Guard cot, away in good style, a corner resulting, why in was sent by. Good play by J. Dougan brought, play well down, where Presley missed a good chance of scoring. The Innskillings were now having the best of a good game hut over eagerness spoiled all attempts. Play was now very rough for a while, fools and frees being a disagreeable feature of the game. Higginson indulged in some tricky work but be was not getting enough support from his wing men. Half time was approaching as the Guards name down towards Hewlett, who saved in a brilliant menu. Play was in the Guards' quarters, when half-time was announced, with the score in favor of the Innis killings by 1 goal to nil.

The second half was renamed by the Guards kicking off. The Abrasion hove took play in hand and Hewlett got some stiff shots to save, which he did in fi e style. The Guards had play all in their favor in this half and it speaks volumes for the defense of Hewlett and company that the net wins not pierced. The Guards were playing a go id game in this half but score they could not-as Hewlett was always out the alert, his saves being neat and well executed. With only seven minutes to go the stripes got down towards Hewlett, where Bipin, with a neat grounder, equalized the score. Hats, caps, and sticks were flung in the air. The excitement was intense as Presley sent wide. From this to full t:ms play was oven, an uninteresting game ending in a draw.

div.head: AN UNUSUAL INCIDENT
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir, allow me space in your paper for the following. I was a spectator at the football matoh, Innskillings vs. Coldstream Guards. While the match was in progress I heard several individuals shouting to the players, "Boot him," "Kick him," "Pot the referee off,"

' Play the game., referee," etc. Now the same people attend football matches simply to "pick a row." There is no sport in that. These individuals really don't know what football is. They are not to.be trusted. A roan can shout for his favonrite team, without using words that I would not utter to a dog. In mv opinion, the referee's decisions wore correct.—I am, etc ,

div.head: A Dyspeptic in Despair.
div.p: Complications followed Indigestion,
Rheumatism and Nervous Debility
Haggard with Pain
Feels Years Younger Today
Digestion and Nerves Strengthened by
DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS

MRS.. E. C. Gore, a well-known lady residing at 89, Clatendon- place, Dover, has suffered such prolonged agonies following acute indigestion that she is anxious to tell how Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People restored her debilitated digestive organs, gave her new strength, and so enriched her blood that to-day she enjoys better health than ever before.

' I began to feel run down and depressed," said Mrs. Gore. "People remarked that I was looking ill for my face grew worn. Life seemed to drag, and little journeys tired me exceedingly. The company of friends became distasteful, because I was so irritable and my nerves easily upset.

"One afternoon while shopping a sadden weakness seized me, and the ground seemed to sink beneath my feet. I went home to be; doctors were summoned and prescribed res', bat before long I had violent fits of shivering. My head seemed as though it would split, and I vomited whatever nourishment I took until quite prostrated. My medicine and diet changed, but the terrible achiness continued. I was placed on boiled milk foods to no purpose. My tongue became thickly coated ; appetite I had none, of course, and soon I foil away to a shadow. Every breath felt like a knife striking my longs, and heavy, doll pains long over my heart. The doctors then called in a specialist, when my husband was told that I was a victim of acute dyspepsia and nervous debility.

"Stiffness settled in my joints, and my limbs were racked with shooting pains through my elbows and fingers and from my knees to my toes. Every muscle in my body felt as if constantly being severed with red hot knives. I became so tender that I could not bear to be moved. Doctors said they could not do more for me The poisons in my system had set op Rheumatism, and I lingered on exhausted by pain. Friends gave me np, and, indeed 1 could have died had it not been for Dr. Williams' Pink Pills.

'One night- my husband said he would get, a box of Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for me, as he, had read about their many sores. To phase, him I promised to try these pills. I did so), and in time made an amazing recovery. First the sickness ceased, and I began taking milk food with relish I felt hungry. Then 1 ate light meals without any sign of indigestion. My husband was delighted. I took six boxes before I was able, to get about on my feet. Then my back grew stronger, and I lost all pain in my joints. I had no difficulty in breathing, and my nerves . I recovered before I had finished the sixth box, while the rheumatoid poisons were , driven out of the blood. Now I feel years younger. I do my homework without fatigue. I feel bright and happy, and never have headaches or backaches. Dr. Williams' Pink Pills have restored me to perfect health."

Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People actually make Good, Red Blood that builds up the system anew and gives strength to the vital organs. They have also cured Eczema, Rheumatism, Sciatica, Neuralgia, St. Vitus' Dance, Rickets, Paralysis, Loco- I motor away, and Ladies' Ailments. div.head: PROSPECTUS
div.p: FONDATION DE LA SOCIÉTÉ—La Société Anonyme THE ARTESIAN BORING & PROSPECTING Co. a été autorisée par Démet Khédivial du 15 Mai 1904.

OBJET — Bile a ponre bot : le forago et l'installation de puits dits artésiens, soit poor l'alimentation en eau potable des villes et des particuliers, soit ponr l'irrigation des terres ; l'acquisition de terrain» susceptible» d'être cultivés giate a l'irrigation artésienne et antres ; l'exéontion de toute» sortes de sondage» et forageB profonds ponr recherohes minières ; l'obtention ot l'exploitation de toutes concessions de recherches.
TRAVAUX EXÉCUTÉS :

a) IRRIGATIONS.—La Société a exécuté depuis sa fondation on grand nombre d'installations d'irrigation artésienne, et elle a en mains ponr plus de L.B 20,000 de nouveaux contrats, dont plosioors concernent des installations devant fournir phaoune environ 30,000 ms d'ean par jour. Le nombre toujoors omissent do commandes de pnita artésiens provient :
1* de ce que l'irrigation artésienne permet d'éviter les inconvénients da système des rotations
2* de Ia.jpiee en ooltnre de nombreux terrains auxquels fait défaut tonta irrigation par l'eau du Nil.

B) ALIMENTATIOMS EH BAU POTABLB —La Société a aohové plnsionrs installations en ean potable pour lo compte d'AdmÍD¡8tratior,B Gouvernementales et de partiouliers, entre autres celle de la ville de Kbartoum. Elle vient d'être chargés do l'exé- catioD de la partie hydraulique ponr les foornitnres en eau potable des villes de Mennnf et Zagszig.

C) FORAGES PROFONDS.—La Société possède des outillages à vapear pour sondages et forages a grande profondeur. Un forage a 800 pieds a été fait a Port Sudan et on autre de 600 a 1,000 pieds de profondonr est en conrs d'oxéontion dans la même localité. Le Gouvernement a également chargé la Société do faire à Mersa Matrooh nn rondage de 700 pieds poor recherche d'ean douce. Un sondage de reohorohea été exécuté a 400 pieds de profondonr pour le compte do l'Egyptian Coal Syndicate.

CONCESSIONS.—La Société a obtenu du Gouvernement une concession de 5 100 feddans de terraine onltivables dans le district de Mersa Matroch ot de 12.0CO m2 de terrain a tâtir le long de port de cette mémo looalité.
Cotte conceasion est appetée an pins grand avenir par anite de l'achèvement prochain dd ohemin de fer construit par Son Altse le Khédive sur la côe Oaest d'Alexandrie.

RESULTATS OBTENUS.—Il a été distribué 6% pour le 1er exercice; 9% ponr 10 2me après amortissement de tons frais de premier établissement et de 20 % snr la valear dn matériel. Les compte» ariê'é» provisoirement an 8 Novembre 1906, aoonsent déjà ponr les 8 premier» mois dn 3me exeroiop, actuellement en cours et se terminant le ,81 Mars 1907, tin bénéfice de pins de 20 % du capital, dédnotion faite de tons irais d'exploitalion et d'administration. Les affaires actuellement eancluee, dont la pies grande partie no »'achèveront qu'au conrs de l'exeroice proohain, assurent d'oros et déjà a ellos sealos un bénéfice suffisant pour rémunérer le nouveau oapital émis.
AUGMENTATION DU CAPITAL —Les fonda provenant de la nouvelle émission seront affeotés prioipabmeut à;
1 —La mise en valeur de la concession do Mnrsa Matrooh.
2.—L'acquisition et la mi-e en voleur de teireins susceptibles d'être exploités an moyen d'irrigation artésionno.

3. - L'extenaion des entreprises de forages profonds pour recherohes minières. La Société a déjà fait les preuves. Les résultats qii'elle a pu obtenir aveo on oapital aussi minime quo oeloi dont elle a disposé jotqo'à présent, montrent on qu'elle pourra réaliser lorsque sea reasourcoa lui permettront do porter ion activité dans les diverrea branches que sea Statut» l'autorisent a exploiter.

Applications must be made to the Service des Recettes before Febrary 18, 1907., Sundays and holidays excepted, by the owner, so as to have the plaques or distinctive marks put on to their vehicles. After the above date, if any of the above mentioned vehicles are found circulating without a plaque or distinctive mark, their owners will be liable to prosecution.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: There will be two appointments for Doctors in the Sudan Medical Department made about April next.
Candidates should forward all testimonials to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum.
Information is to ago, qualifications, engagements since qualifications, is required.
Candidates should be about 26 years old and unmarried, and should have a good knowledge of English and Arabic. Egyptians will be preferred.
Salary to commence at the rate of L.E. 20 per pensem, eligible for increase after two years' satisfactory service.
Applicants should be prepared to appear for interview about the 2nd week in March 1907, in Cairo.
Appointment for probation 3 months, after-wards for a year before being permanently admitted into the Government service.
Sudan Agency,
War Office, Cairo.

PICTURE POST CARDS
TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange thigs as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them we fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in j which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little winner time the Riviera, amid ' possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than ninny other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far-too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio- Rubattino Co's steamers, which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about the hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a tine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless source of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in BC 413, and taken by the Romans in BC 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000' inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Erimiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from J Palermo by the Florio Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places j on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The I small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of live hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not he omitted. The Casein« is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Vidale dri Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hit's a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Valtom- brusa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet, above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog wheel railway to Saltiiio. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a line Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. Oho of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a ; very convenient half-way lions, between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba). — The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature— warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa, Thun there are the Superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only ' three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy ' before making the tour of the Lakes. The, Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo Sun Domino and in half an hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: SALSOMAGGIORE (Italy.)
div.p: A pleasantly situated village lying in the valley between Piacenza and Parma, rapidly becoming famous for its waters, which are very rich in bromine and iodine, and the richest in the world in lithium, strontium, and ichthyol, and have been successfully used in the treatment of regcrofula, rheumatism, tuberculosis affections, ladies' complaints, etc.

The steamers of the P. & O., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P. & O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste-Vienna express from Alexandria.

THe quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris: and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after recieving the Indian

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued)
div.p: and
The ITALIAN LAKES.

VENICE is a 5 hours' journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach the Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other seaport. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza: -

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. - CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Trenuszo; Cadenabhia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezze along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable A steam tram rims from Maggit to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two and three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Like of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M San Salvatore, M. de Caprino and M. Gencroso.

LOCARNO may he reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Cisori, and "The Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE.—A striking picture on the Lake ; of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous

7'he Lake of Lucerne abounds m delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burkenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery of the trip from Lucerne to Eluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluolen runs the famous Axentrasset

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. -et and quaint; sheltered from winds ; just the place to rest and recreate. Beautiful walks, thro1 gh woods, and alone the lake shore. Kuraaal, Concerts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERLAND.— INTER-LAKEN, a favourite summer resort, and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Junafrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also het far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbacci, Trummelbach and Staubbach Then also tho glaciers of Grindelwald view from Murren and the Schyriige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft. above the sea on the now Electric Railway between Montecux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, ns it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivihal Mail Co. and Russian Steam Navigation Co

If possible, tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara. for which a special train is run from Athens.

mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay. These small but, comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry boats," having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

Gentleman,

TEN years ago we established in London the CAXTON TYPE FOUNDRY to manufacture Printing Types on the interchangeable tune and labor-saving principles of Standard Point Line, and Point Set on Point Body. We claimed, and have established the statement, that the exclusive use of Caxton Printing Types would give one-fourth of the compositors time in the setting of all kinds of hand composition. At the present time over 10,000 Printers in the United Kingdom. Australasia, Canada. Africa, the Indian Empire and other British possessions are customers of the Caxton Type Foundry.
As is well known, the type industry of America is controlled by a type TRUST: and in the United Kingdom by a similar organization known as the type RING of British Type Manufacturers.

The CAXTON TYPE FOUNDRY was founded to oppose all such combinations. It is independent of all such connections, and is therefore, selling type at a loner price, and furthermore, guarantees to sail at the same price in all parts of the British Empire.

Another branch is the CAXTON WOOD MILLS, the largest and most complete Wood Working-Plant in the British Empire exclusively employed in the production of space and labour-saving woodwork for Printers. We have made a specialty of Using hard wood exclusively m all our productions. Wood Furniture and Reglet is made out of Tungatone. especially close-grained Wood which is so heavy that it sinks in water, and is therefore particularly/valuable.

We are also makers of the widest and /the most complete range of PLATEN PRESSES in the World, comprising tlio wall-known "Caxton" Platen, for fine work: the light-running "Swift" Platen for small printers: the Haddon "Improved Gordon.' suitable for any jobbing printer: the Haddon Safety Platen, capable of printing 2.500 full formes per hour: the Haddon "Improved Victoria, modelled on the Cropper principle, but superior m construction and output.
We invite enquiries, when complete Catalogues with all details will be sent post free.
Yours faithfully,
JOHN HADDON & CO.
As.at for Egypt : JEFFREY W EADY.
Chereah Moatas. Boulevard Mohamed Aly. Cairo.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien AVIS
div.p: L'Administration dos Chemins de for de l'Etat Egyptien a l'honneur d'informer le public qu'à partir du Dimanche 10 Février jusqu'a nouvel avis, il ne sera pins attaché de wagons lits anx traius de noit Nos. 33 et 34. partant do Caire et d'Alexandrie, à 11 h. 30 m. du soir.
Néanmoins les voyageais de promière classe, voyageant par ces trains, pourront lorer des ooussina et des couvertures moyennant paie- mont d'uno taxe de 10 piastres tarif.
G. B. MACAULET, Directeur Général.
Le Caire, le 1er Février 1907.

div.p: Remède souverain pour la guérison rapide des irritations de poitrine, des rhumes, maux de gorge, rhumatismes, douleurs. Exiger le nom Wlinski. 8-1)
Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
